solution_03_central_limit_theorem/03_central_limit_theorem/13_binom_more_v2

video

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. \[\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (165)(0.14) ~=~ 23.1\] \[\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(165)(0.14)(0.86)} ~=~ 4.4571291 \]

We determine a \(z\)-score. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used \(\sum x\) to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use \(x\) as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) \[\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{19.5-23.1}{4.4571291} \\\\ &= -0.8076948 \end{aligned}\]

Then, find the standard normal probability.

\[P(Z > -0.8076948) ~=~ 0.7903669 \]

Of course, you could have rounded \(z\), so the following will also get credit. \[P(Z > -0.81) ~=~ 0.791 \] \[P(Z > -0.8) ~=~ 0.7881 \]
